page.title: 18THE VILLAGE OF HINXHILL
page.content: The name Hinxhill is thought to come from Hengist Heille, the place of Heng- ist,a 5th century ruler of Kent. There are only 17houses in the village and the church is the most important building.You enter through a lytch gate erected in memory of Rev. John Philpot. It has a variety of carvings made of wood.As you enter the church a flood of yellow light welcomes you through the stained glass window at the E. end of the aisle.There is enough seating for 155 so it is only filled on special occasions.Residents take it in turns to clean and change the flowers every two weeks.The nave and chancel are Early - English and the date 1633 is carved on the timber chancel arch. Beside the church is Court Lodge Farm; one of the buildings was the original Manor of Hinxhill.The present Hinxhill Court is built on the old Rectory site.
